question.text: I found the key I had lost.
This is the key opens the front door.
What’s the name of the tall man #singletouch just came in?
It’s a book #singletouch will interest children of all ages.
The course is for people #singletouch are scared of flying.

exercise.rubric: Are these sentences right: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.input_text: Who’s the girl <gap/> with your brother?
question.text: who’s dancing
dancing
I like people <item>who</item> smile a lot.
I like people <item>that</item> smile a lot.
I forget most of the films <item>which</item> I see.
I forget most of the films <item>that</item> I see.

exercise.rubric: Is this sentence right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: Here’s an article which it might interest you.

exercise.rubric: Do you need to add punctuation to these sentences: yes (Y) or no (N)? When you have checked your answers, correct the sentences if you need to add punctuation.

question.text: The man who cleans my windows has hurt his back.
Fred who cleans my windows has hurt his back.

answer.right: Fred, who cleans my windows, has hurt his back.

question.text: #singletouch she said made me very angry.
The things #singletouch she said made me very angry.
Why can’t you give me #singletouch I need?
The only thing #singletouch keeps me awake at night is coffee.

exercise.rubric: Are the endings right: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.input_text: I do a lot of walking, ...
question.text: ... <item>and this</item> keeps me fit.
... <item>which</item> keeps me fit.
... <item>what</item> keeps me fit.
The teacher <item>I like best</item> is my English teacher.
The teacher <item>who I like best</item> is my English teacher.
The teacher <item>whom I like best</item> is my English teacher.

exercise.rubric: Choose the right options. If both are possible, select ‘both’.

question.text: That’s the girl #singletouch works with my sister.
August 31st is a national holiday #singletouch everybody dances in the streets.
The house #singletouch I live is very small.
Tuesday’s <item>the only day that is possible</item> for our meeting.
Tuesday’s <item>the only day possible</item> for our meeting.
Where’s the girl <item>who</item> sells the tickets?
Where’s the girl <item>that</item> sells the tickets?
This is Naomi, <item>who</item> sells the tickets.
This is Naomi, <item>that</item> sells the tickets.
What exactly does this sentence mean?
question.input_text: Megan’s having a party for the people in the office, who are friends of hers.
option: All the people in the office are Megan’s friends.
Megan has only invited those people in the office who are her friends.
question.answer: All the people in the office are Megan’s friends.

question.text: She was a star <item>whose</item> face was on magazine covers around the world.
It was a meeting <item>whose</item> purpose I didn’t understand.
I’ll give you <item>what help I can</item>.
I’ll give you <item>any help that I can</item>.
#singletouch money he has comes from his family.

exercise.rubric: Would these sentences be normal in a formal written report: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.text: The people <item>who</item> live next door reported a disturbance.
The people <item>that</item> live next door reported a disturbance.
We were shown the room the two burglars <item>were caught in</item>.
We were shown the room <item>in which</item> the two burglars <item>were caught</item>.

exercise.rubric: Are the sentence endings possible: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.text: ... to invite.
... whom to invite.
... to play tennis with.
... whom to play tennis with.
... with whom to play tennis.
Did you like <item>the wine which we drank</item> last night?
Did you like <item>the wine we drank</item> last night?
I poured him <item>a glass of wine</item>, <item>which he drank </item>at once.
I poured him <item>a glass of wine</item>, <item>he drank</item> at once.
Which sounds more natural: A or B?
option: Have you got something <item>which</item> belongs to me?
Have you got something <item>that</item> belongs to me?
question.answer: Have you got something that belongs to me?

exercise.rubric: Are these sentences right: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.text: He’s written a book <item>whose</item> name I’ve forgotten.
He’s written a book <item>the name of which</item> I’ve forgotten.
He’s written a book <item>that</item> I’ve forgotten <item>the name of</item>.
He’s written a book <item>of which</item> I’ve forgotten <item>the name</item>.
He’s married to a woman <item>of whom</item> I’ve forgotten <item>the name</item>.

exercise.rubric: What is the difference between these two sentences?

question.text: I have some friends <item>whose house</item> looks over a river.
I have some friends <item>with a house that</item> looks over a river.

exercise.rubric: Are these sentences right: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.text: He lost his temper, <item>at which point</item> I decided to go home.
He lost his temper, <item>which point</item> I decided to go home <item>at</item>.
He lost his temper, <item>at what point</item> I decided to go home.
I’ll never forget <item>the day when</item> I first met you.
I’ll never forget <item>the day</item> I first met you.
Do you know <item>a shop where</item> I can find sandals?
Do you know <item>a shop</item> I can find sandals?
The man <item>who I work for</item> is ill.
The man <item>for who I work</item> is ill.
This is for <item>whoever wants it</item>.
Take <item>whatever you want</item>.
I often think about <item>where I met you</item>.
Look at <item>how he treats me</item>!
I rang Mrs Spencer up, who did our accounts.

exercise.rubric: Are these sentences right: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.text: <item>It’s me that am</item> responsible for the planning.
<item>It’s me that’s</item> responsible for the planning.
<item>It is I who am</item> responsible for the planning.
<item>It is I who is</item> responsible for the planning.

exercise.rubric: Are these sentences right: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.text: I wish the children had a garden <item>in which to play</item>.
I wish the children had a garden <item>which to play in</item>.
I wish the children had a garden <item>to play in</item>.
He’s got <item>a new car that</item> goes like a bomb.
He’s got <item>a new car, which</item> goes like a bomb.
Which sentence is right?
option: This is the woman <item>that Anna said</item> could show us the church.
This is the woman <item>that Anna said that</item> could show us the church.
question.answer: This is the woman that Anna said could show us the church.

question.text: I am enclosing an application form, <item>which I should be grateful if you would fill in and return</item>.
I was driving a car <item>that I didn’t know how fast it would go</item>.

feedback.desc:
This structure is only found in speech, not in writing.
237.18

question.text: [at a formal meeting]: Is there anyone present wants to add any comments?
[in a conversation]: There’s a guy lives downstairs plays the trumpet.
